text:
Late to the thread.

Also running a content operation at an SEO agency.

I generally am OK with one-off requests for another day (I kind of build in sacrificial time into our editorial operations for this sort of thing). But our agency and client load is growing, which means we’re scaling, which also means missed deadlines screws up our weekly planning. As we scale and I hand off more day-to-day editorial tasks, we need to tighten up on some writers.

I tend to have a good rapport with our writers, and seldom do I drop the hammer unless certain writers become reliable disappointments. The line gets blurred when I have a really great SME for a niche topic who I’d prefer to give some slack in exchange for the superb copy they produce. But I don’t have such patience for sloppy work, and tend to reduce or eliminate the work orders I assign to those folks.

The idea of a strike system written into our contracts is the next step for us, appreciate y’all who mentioned that here. Incentives for writers doesn’t appeal to me. I tend to give more work and sometimes offer higher rates to writers who consistently hit copy deadline.

One side note: I have a few writers who have day jobs and freelance on the side. I’m never their top priority, so when SHTF in their job, I have no recourse except to wait (or cancel the job). I hire a few of these folks because they’re experts in a particular topic but generally stick to freelancers.
